title.rendered: Fake stores, imposters and other online shopping scams

content.rendered:
(Click on the CC button of the video to select the subtitles in Spanish)

In Spanish

The percentage of purchases made online has been increasing for many years, and the coronavirus pandemic greatly accelerated this trend. E-commerce sales exceeded $870 billion in 2021, a figure that represents an increase of more than 50% compared to 2019, according to Digital Commerce 360, a company specializing in retail sector research.

Cybercriminals have not been left behind. Scams related to online shopping are the most frequently reported to the Better Business Bureau (BBB), accounting for 37% of complaints filed in 2021 with the BBB scam tracker, and the riskiest, with 3 of every 4 victims reporting loss of money. In a study sponsored by AARP and conducted by Javelin Strategy & Research, it was found that 29% of consumers age 50 and older have been victims of online shopping scams.

These scams typically start with a spoofed website, mobile app, or—increasingly—a social media ad (the BBB found in research that 40% of the complaints it received on related to online shopping scams had originated on Facebook or Instagram).

The typical shopping scam begins with a fake website, mobile app, or social media ad. Some fake e-shops are invented from scratch, but many mimic well-known retailers, with familiar logos and taglines and a URL that is easily mistaken for the real thing. They offer popular items at a fraction of the usual cost and promise perks like free shipping and overnight delivery, taking advantage of the fact that online shoppers appreciate discounts and speed.
